More broadly, this study illustrates that directors not only react to aggregate support realized in elections, but they also respond to the disparate interests of individual shareholder blocks. The influence of such constituencies is largely facilitated by the dispersion of ownership for many large companies. Nonvalue-maximizing entities, such as union pension funds, and potentially public pension funds, family shareholders, government owners, etc., have more sway when their shareholdings are relatively larger. In these circumstances, their votes are likely to be important for issues such as labor relations, board characteristics, management compensation, and other decisions where directors have influence.  

The efficiency implications of disparate shareholder preferences are unclear. Union pension funds may be fully acting in the best interests of pension fund participants and increasing total surplus for all stakeholders. Conversely, other activists might be raising equity value at the expense of total gains for all constituents. Identifying the effects of disparate shareholder interests on value creation as well as value distribution is an important issue that needs to be addressed in future research.  

## Appendix 1:  

### Union Relations  

I construct estimates of employee-union affliation across all sample firms, using a variety of publicly available sources. There is no centralized, publicly available database that contains information on firm employee-union associations; I consult data sources that have been used by previous researchers (Dinardo and Lee 2004; Cutcher-Gershenfeld and Kochan 2004; Gomez and Tzioumis 2006 are recent examples).  

First, I search the 2006 10-K filings for each company in the AFL-CIO portfolios. Some firms do not have 2006 10-K's, due in part to mergers, acquisitions, or exchange rules; for these firms, I rely on the most recent 10-K available (prior to 2006). If no 10-K is available, I consult the 2006 or most recent annual report prior to 2006 released by the firm itself (available online or through investor relations departments). If the 10-K or equivalent annual report explicitly states that none of the U.S. full-time equivalent workers in the firm belong to a union or are subject to a collective-bargaining agreement, I categorize the firm as “"non-union."  

If the 10-K does not explicitly state that a firm's domestic workers are nonunionized, then I consult the U.S. FMCS listing of F-7 notices from January 2003 to December 2006 to identify expiring union contracts. These data are available through a Freedom of Information Act request. For each company in the AFL-CIO sample, I search for the company name under the “Employer” field in each F-7 notice. I check the industry description in the F-7 filing with the SIC code and industry description of the firm in the 10-K and verify that the F-7 notice is not identifying spurious firm names or contracts for firm subcontractors. Then, for each company with F-7 notices, I identify the total number of workers associated with AFL-CIO-affiliated unions and CTW-affiliated unions. The union name and size of the bargaining unit associated with each firm are available in the F-7 notice. For each firm, I sum the numbers of workers in bargaining units associated with each labor organization. If the percentage of workers belonging to unions associated with the CTW Coalition isgreater than $90\%$ ,I categorize the firm as CTW; otherwise, if at least $10\%$ oftheworkersbelong to an AFL-CIO union, the firm is categorized as AFL-CIO.  

Some firms explicitly state which unions are associated with their workers in the 10-K; if no FMCS filings are available for these firms, I rely on information in the 10-K's to estimate union workforces. Six firms (railroads and airlines) are not covered under the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA), mandating that the FMCS must be notified of expiring union contracts. Based on information in the 10-K's and discussions with the firms’ investor relations departments,  

I categorize these firms as “AFL-CIO firms." The results are similar if we exclude these six firms fromthesample.  

If a firm does not explicitly state that it has union workers and there are no F-7 notices associated with the firm from 2003 to 2006, I categorize the firm as “non-union." There are several firms that suggest in the 10-K's that they employ union workers; however, I do not find an F-7 notice for these firms. For this small subsample of firms,I consult additional sources in order to more precisely identify employee-union affiliation. First, I look at FMCS filings for 2001-2007. This yields F-7 notices for four companies; using the latest F-7 notice available, I categorize the firm as AFL-CIO or CTW, depending on the affiliation of the union described in the filing. The findings are similar if these four firms are excluded from the sample. For the remaining companies in the subsample, I then consult NLRB elections and petitions from 2001 to 2007 (limiting the search to elections with twenty workers or more, following Dinardo and Lee 2004). For two firms, these data yield union information and hence union categorization. The results are similar if we exclude these two firms from the sample. Finally, I contact the investor relations departments for remaining firms and am able to ascertain the union affiliation of workers at four firms: Affiliated Computer Services and VF Corporation, which are both categorized as CTW firms, and Decoma and Magna International, which are both categorized as AFL-CIO firms. The results are similar if we exclude these four firms from the sample.  

There are several potential sources of measurement error; however, it is likely that this measurement error causes voting pattern estimates to understate the true impact of union worker interests on proxy voting. First, FMCS data may be missing some unions or firms that do not comply with the legal requirements of the NLRA (leading to downward bias in union representation). Second, I utilize U.S. government filings; I restrict the unionization estimates to include U.S. full-time equivalent employees who are unionized—not international workers who may belong to a labor union, since data on international unionization are not standardized across firms. Third, for each company, I search the FMCS and NLRB filings, using only the primary company name associated with the ticker symbol—not uniquely named subsidiaries for each firm. Sometimes subsidiaries will be listed alongside the parent company name in F-7 notices and this will be included in the dataset; other times a subsidiary will have a different name from the parent company and this will not be included in the dataset. I assume that the F-7 notices associated with a parent company are representative of the F-7 notices associated with a parent company and all of its subsidiaries.  

## Appendix 2:  

### NLRB Unfair Labor Practice Data  

There are primarily two types of unfair labor practices (ULP). First, collective bargaining ULP's are charges filed by labor unions against firms in violation of Section 8(a)(5) of the NLRA, which stipulates that an employer cannot “refuse to bargain collectively with the representatives of his employees, subject to the provisions of section 9(a)” where section 9(a) reads:  

Representatives designated or selected for the purposes of collective bargaining by the majority of the employees in a unit appropriate for such purposes shall be the exclusive representatives of all the employees in such unit for the purposes of collective bargaining in respect to rates of pay, wages, hours of employment, or other conditions of employment: Provided, that any individual employee or a group of employees shall have the right at any time to present grievances to their employer and to have such grievances adjusted, without the intervention of the bargaining representative, as long as the adjustment is not inconsistent with the terms of a collective-bargaining contract or agreement then in effect: Provided further, that the bargaining representative has been given opportunity to be present at such adjustment.  

Second, unionization ULP's are charge issued by firms against labor unions, in which labor unions are accused of engaging in illegal unionization practices (a violation of Section 8(b)(1)(A) of the NLRA). Section 8(b)(1)(A) specifically stipulates that: It shall be an unfair labor practice for a labor organization or its agents to restrain or coerce employees in the exercise of the rights guaranteed in section 7: Provided, that this paragraph shall not impair the right of a labor organization to prescribe its own rules with respect to the acquisition or retention of membership therein.  

Section 7 states:  

Employees shall have the right to self-organization, to form, join, or assist labor organizations, to bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing, and to engage in other concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining or other mutual aid or protection, and shall also have the right to refrain from any or all such activities except to the extent that such right may be affected by an agreement requiring membership in a labor organization as a condition of employment as authorized in section8(a)(3).  

RAA maintains a database of all individual charges (dockets) filed with the NLRB. I hand collect filings relevant to a particular firm by searching for the firm's name in the “Employer” field of each docket in the database. If there are no unfair labor practices for a given firm, that firm is recorded as having O ULP. I repeat this procedure for every firm in the sample. I search among all ULP charges filed between January 1, 2002, and December 31, 2002, for the pre-sample strife measures used in this article. For within-sample ULP data from January 1, 2003, to December 31, 2006, I utilize data obtained from the NLRB through an FOIA request (RAA does not maintain complete ULP data for this period).

# THE MEDIUMIS THE MEASURE: TECHNICAL CHANGE AND EMPLOYMENT,1909-1949 Michelle Alexopoulos and Jon Cohen\* AbstractNew indicators, based on technology titles, are used to measure the impact of innovative activity on the U.S. labor market between 1909 and 1949. We find that positive technology shocks raised productivity, employment, vacancies, and labor turnover and lowered unemployment and business failures. Moreover, automotive and electrical innovations (quintessentialgeneral-purposetechnologies）hadagreater positive impact on employment than those in mechanical innovations. The overall results, compatible with the predictions of the real business cycle model, raise questions about the anemic recovery in employment after 1934 since the strong upsurge in technical change failed to be accompanied by vigorousjobexpansion. ## 1. Introduction movements in output, hours, and employment at business cycle frequencies is a subject of intense debate among macroeconomists. The debate is concerned largely with the degree to which technology shocks explain both cyclical fuctuations in the labor market and the response of labor market variables to the shocks.1 For example, in standard New Keynesian models with sticky prices and nonaccommodating monetary policy, it is argued that for the most part, demand, not technology, shocks account for cycles in output and employment, and, at least initially, a positive technology shock leads to a short-run drop in employment and/or hours worked.? In standard neoclassical models, rigidities are absent, and technology shocks drive cycles and have an immediate positive effect on employment. It follows then that the use of direct measures of technical change in an analysis of business cycles should contribute to resolution of the debate in that they will allow us to determine empirically the impact of technology shocks on both cyclical fuctuations and short-run employment opportunities. With these considerations in mind, we run a series of vector autoregressions for the period 1909 to 1949, employing new direct measures of technical change, to pinpoint the impact of technology shocks on both cycles and labor market variables.3 Our choice of time period is intentional. While most participants in this debate, with the notable exception of Francis and Ramey (2004), focus on the post-World War II years, there are compelling reasons to look at the earlier decades of the last century. First, the U.s. economy was subject to more frequent, longer, and deeper business cycles (including, of course, the worst on record) during the first half of the twentieth century than during any subsequent period. Second, the 1920s and, especially, the 1930s were decades of rapid technical progress where significant advances occurred across a large number of industries and types of innovations, including two major general-purpose technologies (GPT)—electricity and automobiles—and one near GPT—machinery.4 Third, high rates of unemployment dogged the U.S. economy throughout the 1930s, even after recovery started in 1934 and as technical change hit record highs. President Roosevelt, along with many in his administration, seemed to believe that these technical advances were major contributors to the paucity of new employment opportunities (Bix, 2000). Others, such as Cole and Ohanian (2004), contend instead, that it was the very policies introduced by the administration to abet recovery that held back job growth. As we explain below, our new indicators allow us to evaluate the validity of Roosevelt's beliefs and help us determine technology's role in the recovery. We use two sets of measures in our analysis. The first consists of the annual technical change indicators presented initially in Alexopoulos and Cohen (2009), which covers 1909 to 1949 and is based on information in the Library of Congress's (LOC) MARC record database. The second is entirely novel: It measures innovations at monthly frequencies from 1920 to 1949 and is created from the publication lists in R. R. Bowker Company's Publisher's Weekly (PW). Both sets embody the full range of features considered desirable in such indicators: they are objective, consistent over time, and they capture innovations at the moment of their commercialization. They suffer from few of the shortcomings associated with traditional direct measures and, unlike indirect ones such as those based on cleansed Solow residuals or long-run restrictions, focus unambiguously on new technologies.5 The new indicators have an additional attractive feature. Since they allow us to break down overall technical advances into various subgroups, such as electrical, automotive, and mechanical (our GPT and near-GPT technologies), they enable us to quantify the importance and impact of different types of technological change (GPT versus non-GPT, product versus process) on productivity and the labor market. The monthly measures, moreover, allow us to examine the impact of technology shocks on labor market variables in various subperiods and thus check the robustness of results based on the annual indicators. To summarize our findings briefly, we observe, first, in keeping with Francis and Ramey (2004), a positive relationship between aggregate technology shocks and employment in the short and medium runs at both annual and monthly frequencies. In short, even if the economy was saddled with frictions, imperfections, or price and wage rigidities, they were insufficient to offset the positive impact of technical change on employment. Second, we find that our bookbased measures of technology explain a significant portion of the variance in employment, especially at monthly frequencies. Third, consistent with the predictions of a standard search model, while innovations during this period created new jobs, destroyed old ones, and altered skill requirements, the bottom line is that, overall, they boosted job opportunities: vacancies rose and the unemployment rate fell as a direct consequence of technical change.6 Fourth, our data suggest, in keeping with the literature on postwar labor markets and technical change, that the introduction of new technologies increased labor market turbulence in the manufacturing sector: the median layoff rate dropped, while the gross accession rate, total separations, quits, and discharges all increased.′ Fifth, we find that despite the turbulence in the labor market, technical change during this time period was associated with fewer business failures. When we disaggregate by type of technology, our results indicate that the quintessential GPTs (automotive and electrical) had a greater positive impact on employment than those in the one near-GPT (mechanical). The obvious question is, Why the difference? Evidence from the industrial organization literature suggests that both product- and process-based technological change can increase productivity at the firm and industry levels, although their impact on labor demand often differs.8 New products create new markets and usually boost employment, while new processes frequently save labor and may therefore cause employment to fall. Although process advances are present in all of our groups, electrical and automotive technologies also contain strong job-creating product components.” In this respect, it is likely that the Roosevelt administration's preoccupation with the labor-displacing effects of new technologies was largely a consequence of its focus on innovations in manufacturing.10 Had the administration heeded the warning of its researchers and included in its evaluation the rapid growth of new products linked to automotive and electrical advances, it may have been more sanguine about the employment-boosting features of these new technologies. It may even have embraced the idea that the great wave of gadgets that swept over the United States from the mid-1930s actually prevented a bad situation from becoming a good deal worse. As it happens, this is confirmed by the results of our counterfactual analysis. In the absence of positive technology shocks in the 1930s, TFP, per capita hours worked, and private, nonfarm employment would all have been much lower than they actually were and rates of unemployment substantially higher. We proceed as follows. In the next section, we present our annual and monthly indicators of technical change and review their intuitive appeal. In section Il, we examine the response of productivity, labor market variables, and business failures to aggregate technology shocks. In section IV, we first examine the differential effects of various types of technology shocks (GPT, near-GPT, and nonGPT) on employment, unemployment, labor turnovers, and business failures and then present a series of counterfactuals that highlight the crucial role GPT technologies played in recovery from the Great Depression. In section V, we summarize our findings and identify areas for future research. ## I1. Indicators of Technological Change A good indicator of technical change should be consistent over time, objective, quantifiable, and able to capture an innovation at the moment of its commercialization. All the usual suspects fail to meet one or more of these requirements. Research and development expenditures (available annually only after 1953) measure inputs into the inventive process, not outputs of commercially viable innovations. While, as Griliches (1990) and others point out, patent applications and grants do represent potentially valuable new additions to economic knowledge, the long and uncertain lags associated with their commercial adoption make them at best imperfect indicators for our purpose. They are, in addition, compromised for the 1930s because a surge in judicial hostility to corporate patents led to a decline in corporate patent applications (Schmookler, 1966). Although innovation counts resolve some of these problems, they are difficult to quantify and are notoriously subjective.11 Finally, while changes in productivity numbers (even those cleansed using techniques proposed by Basu et al., 2006, or Ohanian, 2001) do pick up changes in efficiency, they may be affected by factors other than technical change (e.g., changes in regulations) and thus fail to provide a foolproof measure of commercialized technology. The indicators used here are designed to capture new innovations at the time of commercialization and are derived using the method proposed by Alexopoulos (2008, 2011).12 The annual series we utilize from Alexopoulos and Cohen (2009) are based on new technology titles (excluding new editions) in the MARC (MAchine Readable Cataloguing) records of the LOC. As Alexopoulos and Cohen (2009) demonstrate, there is a close correspondence between the commercialization of major innovations as reported by Mensch (1979) or Jewkes, Sawers, and Stillerman (1969) and its first appearance in book form. As Alexopoulos and Cohen (2009） note,this correspondence between the dates makes perfect sense. Firms must promote their innovations and the publishing industry profits from spreading knowledge about them. For both groups, timing is crucial: too early, and no market is likely to exist for their titles; too late, and the market is likely to be saturated and the information dated. In short, there is every reason to believe that new technology titles closely track the commercialization of new products and processes, especially during this period, when books and manuals were the most common way to disseminate such information. Reliance on annual indicators does have one potential drawback: it may mask within-year short-run movements at business cycle frequencies. To address this problem, we created a new set of indicators based on data drawn from $P W$ a weekly bulletin (with monthly summaries) published by R. R. Bowker. The volumes, intended for use by the procurement staff of libraries and booksellers, contain information by subject area on publisher (only major publishers are included), date and place of publication, language (mostly English), and type.13 Although the indicators based on the $P W$ lists cover a shorter time span than those constructed from the MARC records—they begin in 1920—and are limited to aggregate estimates of innovative activity, they provide a valuable complement to the LOC series since they allow us to examine subperiods and thus to determine if a change in observational frequency alters our results. 14 Both the monthly and annual indicators reveal that the 1930s was indeed a technologically progressive period, with the largest number of innovations occurring in the latter half of the decade, coincident with the rapid increase in productivity.15 There are both similarities and differences in the pattern of ups and downs across subgroups. To summarize briefy, the number of new children's titles does not trace the same trajectory as that exhibited by technology books. Publications in electrical engineering and electronics show a sharp spike in the early 1920s, plummet between 1929 and 1932, and then experience an equally dramatic recovery through 1941. Manufacturing advances begin their upswing a year later and continue to expand fitfully through 1942. Finally, during the war years, the decreases in some subgroups, such as automotive technologies, can be linked to the shift in focus from civilian to military-based innovations (whose titles are cataloged in another class). These variations across indicators are significant for at least two reasons. First, they suggest that the measures represent real differences in innovative activity across subgroups, not mere trends in publishing. Second, these differences permit us to isolate the impact of different technologies on aggregate employment and thus to determine if the effect on labor demand varies, as many claim, across technologies. On the other hand, the fact that the aggregate annual and monthly technology indicators adhere to a similar pattern allows us to use the latter to see if the responses to the shocks change over time. ## IM. The Response of Employment and Productivity to Aggregate Technical Change ### A. The Bivariate Vector Autoregressions The following series of bivariate VARs are used to estimate the relationship between technological change (as measured by our indicators) and productivity, labor market variables, and business failures: $$ Y_{t}=\mathsf{\alpha}+\gamma_{0}t+\gamma_{1}t^{2}+\mathsf{\rho}\mathsf{p}Y_{t-1}+\mathsf{\delta}\mathsf{E}_{t}+\mathsf{\varepsilon}_{t}, $$ where $Y_{t}=[\ln(Z_{t}),\ln(X_{t})]^{\prime}$ ,with $Z_{t}$ representing one of our productivity, labor market, or business failures variables; $X_{t}$ one of our technology indicators (total, manufacturing and mechanical, electrical and electronic, automotive technologies, or railroad); and $E_{t}$ the log of high school graduates per capita in period $t$ (in an attempt to control for the effect of changes in education on publication trends, productivity, and labor demand).16 As in Shea (1998), Alexopoulos and Cohen (2009), and Alexopoulos (2011), we identify technology shocks by assuming that they affect the $Z$ variables with a one-period time lag for both the annual and monthly cases.17 The technology indicators are normalized by the number of new children's titles to control for general changes in the publishing industry.18 TABLE 1.—VARIANCE DECOMPOSITIONS FOR PRODUCTIVITY MEASURERS: SHARES ATTRIBUTABLE TO TECHNOLOGY

Aggregate technological change and productivity.Since technical change exerts its influence on employment, at least in part, through its impact on productivity, it is necessary to explore first the relationship between technology as captured by our indicators and productivity during this period. For the annual analysis, we use the standard TFP and labor productivity measures, while for the monthly cases, since monthly TFP figures are unavailable, we create two labor productivity series: industrial production over aggregate employment for the period April 1929 to December 1949 and manufacturing production over manufacturing employment for the period January 1920 to December 1949.19 The Granger-causality tests (repored in the tables in appendix B) for the bivariate VARs clearly indicate that changes in technology Granger-cause changes in labor productivity at both annual and monthly frequencies (and, for annual data, also TFP) and are for the most part significant at the $5\%$ to $10\%$ levels. Although there is little evidence in the annual data to indicate reverse causality, that is, from productivity to technology, at monthly frequencies, causality seems to run in both directions. In the first three rows of panel A in table 1, we report the variance decompositions (and their corresponding $90\%$ confidence intervals) for our aggregate measures of technical change and productivity at the three-, six-, and nine-year horizons for both the annual and monthly series. First, the variance attributable to the aggregate technology indicators is somewhat smaller for labor productivity than for private nonfarm TFP (e.g., $9\%$ versus $24.7\%$ at the six-year horizon). As expected, the standard errors are larger for the annual than for the monthly data, but in both cases, the relationship between technical change and productivity is positive. Labor Market Responses to Aggregate TechnologyShocks captures the impact of aggregate technical change on vacancies, employment, hours, and the rates of unemployment, quits, layoffs, dismissals, and accession. Together, they provide a comprehensive account of the impact of innovation on the labor market during this period. We now turn to the central focus of this analysis: the relationship between our indicators of technical change and labor market variables. We report two sets of results. The first, using annual data, measures the impact of aggregate technology shocks on employment (total, manufacturing, and transportation), total hours, and unemployment per capita, while the second, based on monthly data from $P W$ Responses of annual variables. The Granger-causality tests (reported in appendix B) indicate that at annual frequencies, the aggregate technology measure does not Granger-cause fluctuations in aggregate employment per capita, aggregate unemployment per capita, per capita nonfarm employment, and private nonfarm hours per capita, but it does Granger-cause fuctuations in per capita manufacturing and transportation employment. Reverse causality is not seen in any of these cases. The impulse responses to a $1\%$ positive aggregate technology shock, reported in panel A in figure 2, are generally consistent with those predicted by a neoclassical business cycle model (or a New Keynesian one with accommodating monetary policy). No matter which measure of employment or unemployment is used, or in which sector, the estimated responses reveal that employment and hours increase and unemployment falls, notably even in the short run. The peak responses for employment occur two to three years following the shock and range from a low of approximately $0.048\%$ for aggregate per capita employment to a high of roughly $0.22\%$ for transportation employment per capita. For unemployment and hours per capita, the maximum responses are approximately $-0.6\%$ and $0.1\%$ , respectively. The responses are significant at standard levels for per capita private nonfarm, manufacturing, and transportation employment. The variance decompositions are presented in the first three rows of panel A in table 2. They indicate that a modest amount of variation in the labor market variables is attributable to aggregate technological change. For example, at the six-year horizon, approximately $10\%$ of the variation in the labor market aggregates, $16\%$ of swings in manufacturing employment, and as much as $27\%$ of the changes in transportation employment appear to be linked to fluctuations in aggregate technology. Monthlylaborvariableresponsestotechnology shocks. Since annual data may be unable to detect the impact of a technology shock on hours or employment within the first year, we repeat our analysis using monthly statistics. The Granger-causality tests (again reported in appendix B) indicate that our new monthly technology indicators Granger-cause movements in aggregate nonfarm employment, manufacturing hours and employment, and the unemployment rate. They also Granger-cause fuctuations in aggregate vacancies and the median manufacturing layoff, discharge, quit, separation, and accession rates. The impulse responses to a $1\%$ aggregate technology shock, and the associated $90\%$ confidence intervals, are depicted in panel B of figure 2. Overall, there is no evidence that hours or employment decrease, even in the short run. In fact, they begin to surge within the first quarter following the shock, while at the same time, the unemployment rate drops below trend and posted vacancies increase consistent with the predictions of a standard labor search model. Vacancies rise by $0.1\%$ , while the maximum change in the unemployment rate is $1.0\%$ . In the eighteen months following the shock, the separation rate increases by 0.84, the quit rate rises by 0.58, the dismissal rate goes up by 0.11, the gross accession rate climbs by 0.95, and the layoff rate falls by 0.45. This increase in labor market turbulence would seem to suggest that while a positive technology shock did create new job opportunities, it also altered skill requirements, causing the need for new matches to be formed. This is supported by a number of the Works Progress Administration studies showing that many firm-worker breakups occurred because workers were either unable or unwilling to be retrained to use the newtechnologies.20 Finally, the results presented in table 3 suggest that our monthly indicators account for a significant share of the variance for all labor market variables at all horizons. A few of these results are of particular interest because of the light they shed on the connection between new technologies and employment. First, over $55\%$ of the short-run variance in vacancies is attributable to innovative activity, an indication that technological change, on the whole, was responsible for many of the new employment opportunities. Second, the large share of the variations in the rates of unemployment, separations, accession, layoffs, quits, and discharges explained by our indicators (between $19\%$ and $27\%$ at the three- to six-year horizons) testifies to the notion that while the new technologies did create jobs, they also contributed significantly to labor market turbulence. ### C. Sensitivity Results As is well known, the period 1909 to 1949 was subject to major economic and policy shocks: two world wars, the Great Depression, the roaring twenties, exit from the gold standard, and Roosevelt's New Deal. An obvious question: Are our results robust to changes in time period or, the same question put differently, are our results driven by some of the unique features of the period? To address this question, we run a number of sensitivity tests across different subperiods, relying for the most part on monthly manufacturing employment in order to maximize the number of observations.21 As the results, based on the response of manufacturing employment to technology shocks for the subperiods January 1920 to October 1929, November 1929 to November 1941, December 1941 to December 1949, and July 1933 to December 1949, reported in figure 3, indicate, while changes in time span do affect standard errors, they do not reverse our initial findings. During the first of these, although technological change was more muted than it would be a decade later and monetary policy independence was constrained by the gold standard, a positive aggregate technology shock still caused a short-run jump in employment; the magnitude of the responses is smaller than for the entire period, but the direction is the same. The results, once again, are reassuring—despite a rise in standard errors, employment opportunities go up in response to a positive technology shock. The third subperiod focuses on the war and the early postwar period. The war, it is often claimed, spurred innovations that contributed to postwar prosperity. In principal, they could also have had a negative impact on postwar employment but we find, once again, that even in the shortrun, employment opportunities rose in response to a positive aggregate technology shock, with magnitudes similar to those obtained in section IllB. In an effort to isolate the impact on our results of Roosevelt's decision to leave the gold standard in June 1933, we look at a fourth subperiod that starts in July 1933 and ends in December 1949. As in the other cases, our results are insensitive to the change in time span: a positive technology shocks boosts employment. A second obvious question is, Are our results sensitive to choice of trend? To begin, we enter the employment series in first differences instead of log levels since, as Fernald (2007) and Gospodinov et al. (2011) indicate, because of potential low-frequency comovements between hours worked and labor productivity, the outcome may be sensitive to this choice. Although our short-run identification strategy may be less prone to this problem than others (see Gospodinov et al., 2011), it is still useful to see if the change matters. The first figure in panel B of figure 3 confirms that first differencing employment does not affect our findings: employment expands in response to a positive technology shock. Moreover, as the remaining figures in panel B show, replacing the quadratic trend with a linear one, or including no deterministic trend at all, leaves our main results unchanged. In our last robustness check, we expand the number of variables in the VAR to include the short-run commercial paper rate and the log of the CPI. Following the literature on monetary policy shocks, we order the employment variable before the interest rates and prices and maintain our assumption that technology affects the economy with only a one-period lag (in this case, one month). As shown in panel C of figure 3, our findings for employment remain the same: prices appear largely unresponsive, and we find no evidence that interest rates were accommodative.23 ### D. The Effect of Technical Change onBusinessFailures Given that technological change appears to create significant turbulence in the labor market, does it have a similar effect on firm entry and exit? While there are limited data on business turnovers during this time, we can gain some insight into the process by looking at business failures for which we do have some data at both annual and monthly frequencies. Again, the results from the bivariate VARs indicate that business failures are Granger-caused by aggregate technology shocks. This is true for both annual total failures and monthly failures for the total private, manufacturing, and trade sectors. The impulse responses to a positive $1\%$ technology shock, along with the corresponding $90\%$ confidence intervals, are reported in figure 4, panel A (for the annual measure) and panel B (for the monthly measures). The results, although merely suggestive of firm turnovers, are interesting. Business failures fall significantly in the period following a technology shock. For the annual case, covering 1909 to 1949, we find that a $1\%$ positive technology shock decreases total business failures by $1\%$ two years following the shock and remains statistically significant for five years. We obtain similar results for the monthly series: failures decline for a full five years with the peak impact occurring approximately two years after the shock. At their peak, monthly failures drop between $0.2\%$ and $0.3\%$ in response to the $1\%$ shock, with the greatest impact felt among wholesale-retail establishments. ## IV. Are All Technology Shocks Created Equal? The answer most economists would give to this question is no, although there is much less agreement about why they have differential impacts on economic activity or even the most appropriate way to distinguish one shock from another. We propose to divide technology shocks into general-purpose (GPT), near GPT, and nongeneral purpose (non-GPT) technology to determine if such a breakdown illuminates the effect of technical change on productivity and employment. There is reason to believe that it does. It is often argued, for example, that the impact of GPTs, unlike near- or non-GPTs, is felt across a broad range of products and processes (see Helpman, 1998). Since a significant number of major breakthroughs in what are considered quintessential GPTs (electrical/electronic, automotive) and near- or non-GPTs (e.g., machinery) occurred during our period, it is an ideal setting for such an investigation. Moreover, as we know from the industrial organization literature, product innovations are likely to have a very different effect on the labor market from process ones.24 As our results, reported below indicate, this distinction does offer compelling insights into how (and by how much) new technologies affect labor markets. ### A. Productivity and General-Purpose Technologies We ran a series of VARs based on our annual indicators (monthly figures from $P W$ cannot be broken down by fields) to determine if there was anything distinctive about the impact of advances in electronics, machinery, and automotive on productivity. The results from the bivariate VARs suggest that innovations in these areas Granger-cause annual productivity fuctuations (often at the $1\%$ level). Moreover, as the variance decompositions reported in panel A of table 1 demonstrate, the impact of innovations in these three areas is large, and the share of the variance attributable to them is far greater than that of the aggregate indicator (the first three rows of panel A). To be more precise, while the latter accounted for $5\%$ of the variation in aggregate labor productivity at the three-year horizon and $10\%$ at the nine-year horizon, and $14\%$ and $27\%$ , respectively, in TFP, these magnitudes jump dramatically when the sample is restricted to GPTs and near-GPTs. For manufacturing/ mechanical, GNP per employee registers $14\%$ and $30\%$ at the three- and nine-year horizons and $13\%$ and $39\%$ for TFP; for electrical, the corresponding numbers are $9\%$ and $18\%$ for labor productivity and $8\%$ and $25\%$ for TFP, and for automotive, $10\%$ and $34\%$ for labor productivity, and $9\%$ and $36\%$ for TFP. In short, both GPT and near GPTs shocks are important drivers of productivity changes. ![](images/b7ea781a219c24b11fdba5a66f44fc11af00e3fad5c6a61c62d82a7658e72e77.jpg) FIGURE 4.—-BUSINESS FAILURES′ RESPONSES TO $1\%$ POSITIVE TECHNOLOGY SHOCKS WITH $90\%$ CONFIDENCE INTERVALS BivariateVARsorderchlogyast.TrivariatARsorderfailuresfirsthnGPT,andnnGPT.llARsncldeaquadratictmetrendandameasuref high shoolcmpleion.hocks areidntiedusng a Cholesky decomposition. As the disaggregated impulse-responses presented in panels A and B in figure 1 show, productivity rises significantly in all cases in response to a $1\%$ positive technology shock at $90\%$ confidence intervals. The $1\%$ shock translates into a peak increase of between $0.8\%$ and $0.12\%$ for labor productivity and between $0.05\%$ and $0.08\%$ for TFP. All responses are statistically significant for five to eight years, with the responses to an automotive or mechanical/manufacturing shock peaking in two years and the maximum response to an electrical/electronics shock occurring in the first year. ### B. Labor Market Responses to GPT and Near-GPTInnovations Are the labor market responses to GPT and near-GPT shocks similar, much as they are for productivity? The simple answer is no. The question, of course, is, Why not? As noted, product and process innovations affect the labor market differently. New (or improved) processes increase the efficiency of production with savings in labor or capital, or both, and while they may lead to price reductions or improvements in product quality, the usual outcome is some combination of higher productivity and lower employment. In contrast, new product innovations, embodied in consumption, intermediate, or investment goods, are believed to lead to increases in employment by tapping into new markets. Since there is strong evidence to suggest that GPTs and near-GPTs differ with respect to their relative mix of process and product innovations (see Lipsey et al., 2005, and Stoszak, 2007), we can use GPT/near-GPT distinction to capture the differential impact of product and process innovations. Consider, for example, automotive technologies. While advances here did reduce transport costs, and thus did save labor for some firms, there was also a huge and growing demand for automotive products by households. Passenger cars generally outsold trucks and buses by a factor of at least four such that automobiles accounted for between $81.5\%$ and $98\%$ of all motor vehicle registrations from 1909 to 1949. Moreover, not only did maintenance and repair outlays ensure a steady demand for automotive parts and service workers, but the ongoing innovation of new goods, such as pneumatic tires and automatic transmissions, also guaranteed a buoyant market for new automobiles and automotive products. As auto ownership grew, so did the number of gas stations and the consumption of gas, from a modest amount in 1909 to 13.6 billion gallons in 1936. As automobiles became speedier and more reliable, the demand for new and better roads expanded—and, as a consequence, so did employment in the construction industry. Street and highway capital as a percent of the total private capital stock almost doubled between 1929 and 1941, from $6.5\%$ to $10.85\%$ . Overall, Abernathy, Clark, and Kantrow (1983) find that for the period 1909 to 1949, about $21\%$ of all known automotive innovations were process related, with the rest, for the most part, tied to new products.25 Electrical innovations trace a similar pattern. While much has been made of the way in which electricity revolutionized the production process, it is important to recall how closely linked it was to the plethora of new household and related products that appeared during this period, creating not only a booming demand for household electrification and lighting, but also giving rise to whole new industries. The period marked the first great upswing in the innovation and adoption of new, electricity-powered household appliances, including the radio, the TV, electric vacuum cleaners, refrigerators, and washing machines. Indeed, even as the economy's industrial and commercial sectors embraced the electrification of production processes, households clamored for these new products. As early as 1929, household expenditures on electrical appliances (excluding electric ranges) and radios alone amounted to over $54\%$ of total expenditures for industrial and commercial electrical equipment. As the data compiled by Greenwood, Seshadri, and Yorukoglu (2005) suggest, by the end of our period, over $50\%$ of households had vacuum cleaners, over $60\%$ had washing machines, and over $90\%$ had electric refrigerators. Not only did the two- to threefold growth between 1929 and 1941 in demand for household appliances give rise to new jobs in manufacturing, it also stimulated employment in the wholesale and retail trades, transportation, and services. There was new work for electricians and others in the building trades since, among other things, homes often had to be rewired to facilitate adoption of the new products (Tobey, 1996). The diffusion of the radio, and later the TV, brought into being whole new sectors (broadcasting, entertainment, news), with the number of radio and TV stations growing from virtually 0 in 1909 to over 2,100 and 100, respectively, by the end of our period. In contrast to these two, technological advances in mechanical/manufacturing were associated, by and large, with process innovations and new investment goods. For example, major headings under the LOC TJ classification include automatic machinery, turbines, steam engineering, motorsand engines (excluding electrical), hydraulic machinery, machine shop practice, hoisting and conveying machinery, lifting and pressing machinery, and agricultural machinery, while the TS classification captures the processes used to manufacture goods, such as steel, iron, metal products, leather, paper, foodstuffs, and textiles, as well as the management practices linked to production and operations. In short, positive technology shocks in electrical and automotive, linked as they were with new products, should have caused employment to rise more than similar shocks in manufacturing/machinery. Our results confirm these expectations. Although, as we noted, productivity was significantly affected by innovations in all these groups, their impacts on labor inputs and unemployment were different. Technical change in automotive and electrical/electronics Granger-caused changes in the labor market variables (see appendix B), but there is virtually no evidence that manufacturing/mechanical innovations (with the exception of those in transportation) significantly contributed to increases in employment, hours, or the number of unemployed workers. The variance decompositions reported in table 2 in panel A show a similar pattern. Thus, while new automotive and electrical technologies explain a significant share of the variations in employment, hours and unemployment at three-, six-, and nine-year horizons across all labor market variables, the same cannot be said for manufacturing/machinery. In more detail, electrical technologies account for $15.6\%$ to $18.4\%$ of the variance in aggregate labor input at the six-year horizon, $14\%$ of the variance in unemployment, $18\%$ in manufacturing employment, and $19.4\%$ in transportation employment. For automotive technologies, the comparable numbers are $38.8\%$ for manufacturing employment and $44\%$ for transportation. In contrast, fuctuations attributable to manufacturing/machinery technical change are much smaller for aggregate employment and hours across all horizons and groupings, with the exception of transportation, and, to a lesser extent aggregate per capita unemployment. The impulse responses to a $1\%$ positive technology shock along with the $90\%$ confidence intervals shown in figure 5 tell a similar story. For example, aggregate employment rises significantly following a technology shock in both electrical/electronic and automotive; in the former, the effect lasts five years and peaks after one or two periods; in the latter, the peak is reached in two to three years. In contrast, the hypothesis that aggregate employment is unaffected by a manufacturing/mechanical technology shock cannot be rejected. For the cases of total hours and unemployment, the results are similar. That is, the responses are statistically significant for automotive and electrical/electronic shocks but insignificant for mechanical/machinery shocks. Per capita hours go up, and unemployment, per capita falls in the short run, and a comparison with the previous results reveals that total hours worked rise more than employment, suggesting technology shocks in these cases also cause hours per employee to increase. Finally, for manufacturing and transportation sectors, in all cases bar one (manufacturing employment following a manufacturing/mechanical shock), responses are both positive and significant. To check the robustness of our results across different time periods and to determine if they are primarily driven by the onset of the Great Depression or World War II, we examine the response of employment to an aggregate GPT shock (created using the sum of the automotive and electrical titles as the technology indicator) for four different subperiods: 1909 to 1933, 1931 to 1949, 1919 to 1941, and 1919 to 1949. The results (found in panel D of figure 3) demonstrate that employment rises following a positive GPT shock in all subperiods. However, it is difficult to argue that our overall results are driven by the early years of the Great Depression given that the 1909-1933 results (which include the onset of the Great Depression) produce an insignificant response, while the 1931-1949 results (which exclude it) are positive and significant. World War $\mathrm{II}$ is also not solely responsible, since the responses for the interwar period are also positive and significant. Instead, it appears that our overall results for 1909 to 1949 are a consequence of the positive, significant relationship that emerges after World War 1. ### C.Business Failures Meet GPT Shocks Do GPTs and near-GPTs have different effects on business failures? The answer is quantitatively yes and qualitatively no. The reasons for the differences, once again, are linked to the process/product distinction. We first briefly outline our results and then propose a way to interpret them. The bivariate VARs displayed in panel A of figure 4 show that a $1\%$ increase in any type of technology shock causes business failures to decline for five to eight years, with the major drop occurring two to four years following the shock. Moreover, a $1\%$ positive manufacturing/mechanical technology shock causes a full $1\%$ decline in failures, whereas a similar-sized automotive or electrical shock has only half this impact. The impact of the shocks, in short, does seem to differ. The variance decompositions, found in panel A of table 4, confirm this pattern. Manufacturing/mechanical technologies account for a significant portion of the variation in business failures during this time $32\%$ and $47\%$ at the three- and nine-year horizons, respectively) compared with those attributable to electrical $9\%$ and $13\%$ at three- and nine-year horizons, respectively) and automotive ( $9\%$ and $31\%$ ). Why the differences? Process innovations, a predominant feature of mechanical/manufacturing technologies, save labor and should unambiguously boost profit margins and survival rates. The effect of product innovations is less clear-cut. They may open up new markets and enhance profits, but they may also increase competition and cut into profitable existing lines of business. For this reason, new product-heavy automotive and electrical technologies are likely to have a more nuanced impact on the bottom line, and thus a moderate effect on business failures. ### D.Trivariate VARs: GPT versus Non-GPT In this section we focus sharply on the GPT/non-GPT distinction in an effort to see if such a division alters our results. Since GPTs, almost by definition, have an impact on non-GPTs, the best way to clarify the issue is through the estimation of a series of trivariate VARs that include, in the following order, the variable of interest such as productivity, one of the labor market variables or business failures, aggregate GPT (based on automotive and electrical books), and non-GPT (created by excluding the automotive and electrical counts from the total technology measure). The shocks are identified using a Cholesky decomposition, where the ordering reflects the pervasive nature of GPTs: it allows commercialized GPTs to affect non-GPTs within the year, but lags the possible impact of latter on the former. As before, we include a quadratic time trend and the education variable, and we normalize by children's titles. The variance decomposition results from the trivariate VARs, presented in the B panels of tables 1, 2, and 4, show the following. GPTs account for a substantial share of the variances in labor productivity $23.5\%$ at the six-year horizon) and TFP $(33.5\%)$ , while the effect of non-GPTs is negligible. The same holds true for the labor market variables. The lion's share of the variance is attributable to GPTs at all horizons, while non-GPTs have almost no impact. At the three-year horizon, the smallest share for the variables considered is found in the case of transportation employment $(11.2\%)$ , with the largest share being seen in the case of manufacturing employment $(22.4\%)$ , with the shares at the nine-year horizon ranging from a low of $17.5\%$ (transportation) to a high of $31\%$ (in manufacturing). In contrast, the shares attributable to non-GPT technologies remain under $2\%$ for all variables. The only dissenting voice comes from business failures where GPTs and non-GPTs have almost identical impacts, suggesting that technological advances in general boost business success. Specifically, $7.6\%$ and $10.4\%$ of the variation of business failures at the three-year horizon can be attributed to non-GPTs and GPTs, respectively, with these shares rising to $15.6\%$ and $13.4\%$ by the nine-year horizon. ![](images/e47d393ae9f540141ac45ddb08699389aafe2144d8f8fa1486df2b32b611db57.jpg) Each panel displays the response to a $1\%$ positive technologyshockand the $90\%$ confidence interval. # Labor and Corporate Governance: International Evidence from Restructuring Decisions JULIAN ATANASSOV and E. HAN KIM ## ABSTRACT Our results highlight the importance of interaction among management, labor, and investors in shaping corporate governance. We find that strong union laws protect not only workers but also underperforming managers. Weak investor protection combined with strong union laws are conducive to worker-management alliances, wherein poorly performing firms sell assets to prevent large-scale layoffs, garnering worker support to retain management. Asset sales in weak investor protection countries lead to further deteriorating performance, whereas in strong investor protection countries they improve performance and lead to more layoffs. Strong union laws are less effective in preventing layoffs when financial leverage is high. MUCH OF THE RESEARCH IN LAW AND FINANCE FOCUSES on the role of legal protection of investors in shaping corporate governance.1 However, investors are but one of many stakeholders. Other stakeholders who participate in governance include labor and management. Labor receives legal protection with substantial variation across countries, and its self-interests often conflict with those of investors, at least in the short run. How do firms respond to these conflicting interests? The answer depends on stakeholders' relative influence on the decision making process, which varies across countries due to political and social factors (Roe (2003)). When investors have greater influence, higher priority is given to enhancing capital value. When labor has greater influence, employee welfare may receive higher priority over value enhancement (Tirole (2001)). This paper investigates how the two stakeholders’ relative influence and firm-level variables interact to affect restructuring decisions when firms suffer a sudden, sharp deterioration in operating performance. We proxy for stakeholders? relative influence at the country level by the strength oflegal protection of investors and labor, using measures compiled by Djankov et al. (2005), Djankov, McLiesh, and Shleifer (2006), and Botero et al. (2004). We examine firms at the onset of declining performance in order to avoid firms with prolonged poor performance that may already have undertaken restructuring measures. Our focus on poorly performing firms is motivated by the possibility that conflicts among stakeholders become more acute when the size of the economic pie shrinks. However, it is not obvious how such conflicts affect the nature and the likelihood of restructuring. On the one hand, conflicts may lead to further deterioration of the firm; on the other hand, the stakeholders may rally around the crisis to improve the firm's chance of survival. We consider three types of restructuring measures: large-scale employee layoffs, top management turnover, and major asset sales. Previous studies suggest that each ofthese improves stock price and subsequent operating performance.2 However, part or all of the shareholder gains may arise at the expense of other stakeholders (Shleifer and Summers (1988)). The sacrificing stakeholders may therefore seek to block these restructuring measures. For example, workers may object to investors’ attempts to replace underperforming management if they fear a new management team would slash jobs, wages, and benefits. If labor laws grant sufficient power to workers to block such actions, the incumbent management may form an alliance with workers to maintain the status quo by forgoing value-enhancing restructuring measures resisted by workers. We argue such an alliance is plausible in countries with strong union power and weak investor protection and discuss the economic links between the competing incentives of management, labor, and investors. The theoretical discussion leads to testable hypotheses about how the nature and the likelihood of restructuring decisions are affected by the relative legal strength of labor visa-vis investors. We test the hypotheses on a sample of 9,923 firms (10,947 firmyears) at the onset of sharply declining operating performance in 41 developed and emerging economies over the period 1993 to 2004. We find that poorly performing firms in stronger investor protection countries are more likely to undertake large-scale worker layoffs and replace top management than those in weaker investor protection countries. These restructuring actions are followed by superior operating performance in all legal environments. Major asset sales are different, however. We observe more asset sales when investor protection is either very strong or very weak. Asset sales in strong investor protection countries are followed by superior operating performance, whereas asset sales in weak investor protection countries are followed by inferior subsequent operating performance.3 The likelihood of value-reducing asset sales increases as collective bargaining and labor relations laws grant more power to labor unions, suggesting that these asset sales are countenanced by workers. In addition, underperforming top managers in low investor protection countries are more likely to retain their jobs as union power increases. These results point toward management-worker alliances motivated by a mutual desire to retain jobs. For such an alliance to work, management needs funds to minimize layoffs and wage cuts. Lacking other means to raise the necessary funds, poorly performing firms sell assets to forestall layoffs even when doing so hurts subsequent operating performance. Indeed, asset sales in weak investor protection countries do not lead to layoffs, whereas in strong investor protection countries asset sales predict layoffs. Other interpretations of our results include: (1) asset markets are undeveloped in weak investor protection countries; (2) assets are sold at fire sales to pay off creditors; and (3) poorly performing managers blame strong unions to avoid accountability. Although these stories partially explain our results, none is fully consistent with the data. We also show that our results concerning layoffs and asset sales are not explained by differences in conditions existing prior to performance declines. Another important facet of labor laws relates to employment contract laws. Rigid employment laws make it difficult for a firm to adjust labor costs. When a firm bears a negative revenue shock, the firm's inability to make adequate adjustments to its labor costs exacerbates the decline in the value ofits assets. Firms operating with this imposed inflexibility may sell their most affected divisions and assets to other firms that can either circumvent the labor regulation or find higher-valued uses through synergies. Consistent with this conjecture, we observe more major asset sales when employment laws are more protective. Firm-level variables also matter in restructuring decisions. Firms with higher leverage are more likely to undertake all three types of restructuring. This disciplining role of leverage shows more bite when investor protection is stronger. More interesting, strong union laws are less effective in preventing large-scale layoffs when firms have higher financial leverage. Ownership concentration also is positively related to all three types of restructuring. For management turnover, the positive relation is significant only when top managers are not major shareholders: A major shareholder-manager is not likely to dismiss herself for poor performance. Asset sales exhibit a similar pattern: Major shareholdermanagers are less likely to sell assets, perhaps because they are reluctant to reduce private benefits associated with a larger asset base. In Section I, we discuss relevant theoretical issues and develop the hypotheses. Section II describes the empirical design, sample construction, and data. Section IHI presents empirical results and robustness checks. We make concluding remarks in Section IV. ## I. Legal Environment and Restructuring Decisions: Development of Hypotheses To analyze the economic links between the competing incentives of workers, investors, and management of poorly performing firms, we assume that (1) shareholders and creditors share a common objective to preserve and enhance capital value,4 (2) top management and workers want to retain their jobs, and (3) top managers are opportunistic, weighing the relative influence of investors and workers and siding with the group that can best help them retain their own jobs. When firms suffer from poor operating performance, shareholders may pressure management to undertake restructuring actions to improve firm performance. Creditors also may demand corrective measures, especially when debt covenants are violated (Roberts and Sufi (2006)). Whether these demands will be executed depends on the firm's governance. If the firm is investor friendly, it is likely to undertake value-enhancing measures; if it is worker friendly, the firm may refrain from actions deemed detrimental to employee welfare. Whether governance favors investors or workers is determined by both firmand country-specific factors (Durnev and Kim (2005). We first consider country factors, as proxied by investor and labor protection laws. We hypothesize that layoffs are more likely with stronger investor protection and weaker union laws. Large-scale worker layoffs tend to lead to direct conflicts between investors and workers. Opportunistic top managers facing potential dismissal for poor performance will weigh the relative influence of investors and workers and side with those with greater influence. How the legal environment affects management turnover is less straightforward. Although the literature has focused on investors’ abilities to remove underperforming managers, workers also can influence the outcome. Replacing top management is an attempt by investors or workers to change the direction of the firm by bringing in new leadership. If a change is necessary for value enhancement, stronger investor rights should increase the likelihood of top management turnover. Workers will not oppose changes if the new management is expected to get the firm out of trouble without employee sacrifice. However, poor performance may be due partly to managers? tendencies to overpay workers (Bertrand and Mullainathan (1999)) and their reluctance to trim an unproductive workforce, because of their desire for the quiet life (Bertrand and Mullainathan (2003)). Workers will be protective of such labor-friendly management because new managers brought in to improve performance may force layoffs and reduce wages. Managers may even collude with workers for mutual protection. Pagano and Volpin (2005) develop a model in which managers collude with workers by bribing them with above market wages to thwart hostile takeover attempts. This collusion hypothesis is supported by evidence provided in Rauh (2006) and Kim and Ouimet (2008).5 Similar collusion is possible when firms suffer poor performance. Facing potential dismissal for poor performance, top managers may form an alliance with labor by abstaining from worker layoffs and wage cuts. Workers, in turn, may help retain such managers if they have sufficient power to affect the decision. Workers influence management retention through several channels. Botero et al. (2004) state “workers, or unions, or both have a right to appoint members to the Board of Directors" (p. 1349) in Austria, China, Czech Republic, Denmark, Egypt, Germany, Norway, Slovenia, and Sweden. Such board representation gives labor a direct means to influence managerial compensation and retention. For example, German firms with more than 2,0o0 employees are required to have $50\%$ worker representation on their supervisory boards responsible for selecting chief executives and reviewing their performance.6 In fact, Botero et al. include the right to board representation as a measure of the strength of union power in their labor law index. Workers also indirectly influence top management retention. They may attempt to retain labor-friendly management by opposing liquidation in favor of reorganization with current management intact, or they may lobby for government bailouts to curtail the urgency for layoffs and management turnover. To achieve these goals, workers may organize strikes against mergers or other methods designed to introduce new management. These direct and indirect worker influences should be more effective when workers are empowered through strong union laws. An alliance between top management and workers may not result from explicit collusion. Managers simply may feel reluctant to cut wages or fire workers with whom they have developed working relationships. This reluctance would be reinforced when unions have the legal means to prevent investor attempts to oust incumbent management. These implicit alliances are expected to be more effective in preventing management turnover in countries with stronger labor union power and weaker investor protection. The recent Volkswagen scandal in Germany, a country with strong union laws,7 illustrates such a management-labor alliance. Volkswagen's top management was under pressure from investors for the firm's poor operating performance: Its EBITDA to total assets ratio was the lowest among the four major automakers in Germany over the 2002 to 2005 period, and it was 13th out of 17 major automakers worldwide over the 2003 to 2005 period.8 In 2005, German state prosecutors accused the top managers of bribery for paying labor representatives on its supervisory board as much as $\$36,000$ per individual for in employee compensation following the adoption of large-scale employee stock ownership plans. The compensation increases are concentrated in firms incorporated in states with business combination statutes, which make Employee Stock Ownership Plans (ESOPs) more effective antitakeover device against hostile takeover attempts. 6 The supervisory board has the power to appoint and dismiss management board members, who report to the supervisory board in the two-tiered board system. See Gorton and Schmid (2oo0) and Fauver and Fuerst (2006) for further discussion of the German board system. 7 The strength of German union laws ranks seventh among our sample of 41 countries, while the strength of its investor protection is slightly below the median (see Table I). 8 The other German automakers are BMW, DaimlerChrysler, and Porsche, and the worldwide list includes Fiat, Ford, GM, Honda, Hyundai, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Peugeot, Renault, Suzuki, and Toyota. pleasure trips to Brazil in return for their support. According to a July18, 2005 Business Week article,"CEOs and top managers depend on votes from the labor reps to be reappointed. Instead of making tough decisions on restructuring or job cuts, German managers are inclined to delay or avoid change and instead curry favor with union bosses sitting on their boards, often to the detriment of their companies"(52). The third type of restructuring, asset sales, is generally considered to enhance value. If a firm sells assets to redeploy underutilized resources to higher-valued uses, asset sales should increase shareholder value. Workers, on the other hand, will resist asset sales if they lead to layoffs or diminish the value of their future claims, such as underfunded health-care and pension liabilities. Workers may not resist asset sales, however, if the sales are part of a delaying tactic to maintain the status quo through a management-worker alliance. To avoid wage cuts and worker layoffs, management may have to sell assets. Because poorly performing firms are typically cash constrained, selling underperforming assets may not be sufficient. They may have to resort to selling assets even if doing so destroys synergies with the remaining assets, thereby reducing value. Even when assets are sold at the fair market value without affecting synergies, using the proceeds to delay necessary cuts in payroll will reduce value. Value-reducing asset sales will be blocked by investors if they have the ability to do so. Since a management-worker alliance requires strong union power, the likelihood of value-reducing asset sales is greater in countries with weaker investor protection and stronger union laws. Conversely, value-enhancing asset sales are more likely in countries with stronger investor protection and weaker union laws. Value-reducing asset sales represent a governance failure. They exacerbate poor operating performance, eventually hurting most stakeholders in the long run, including workers. There are two possible reasons for such a governance failure. First, if a great deal of uncertainty surrounds exogenous variables affecting operating performance, managers and workers may rationally decide on costly delaying actions that would allow them to wait for an outcome, albeit with a low probability, which will more than make up for the value lost due to asset sales. This is analogous to Jensen and Meckling's (1976) asset substitution hypothesis in which shareholders may choose a higher risk, lower NPV project. Delays may also provide managers and workers time to locate alternative jobs. The second reason for a governance failure is a behavioral bias based on the theory that people delay immediate-cost activities and engage in immediatereward activities too soon (O'Donoghue and Rabin (1999)). That is, management delays restructuring decisions with immediate cost to workers and managers even though doing so may lead to an even worse outcome. One way to avoid such a governance failure is for management and workers to bond themselves to actions expected in strong investor protection and weak union law countries. However, Doidge, Karolyi, and Stulz (2007) argue, with supporting evidence, that such mechanisms are either unavailable or prohibitively expensive in countries with poor investor protection. Note that these predictions apply only to union laws. Employment contract laws are another important component of labor laws that may affect restructuring decisions. Botero et al. (2004) construct an index measuring the rigidity of employment laws, which includes the costs of hiring and firing workers, reducing wages, and changing working hours. We hypothesize that inflexible employment laws encourage asset sales during corporate distress. Consider a firm suffering a sharp drop in revenue. If inflexible laws prevent the firm from making the necessary cut in labor costs, the value of its assets utilizing the workforce will decline. The firm may be able to realize higher values by selling the affected assets to other firms that can find a means to circumvent the regulation or redeploy the assets to higher-valued uses. ### I1. Empirical Design, Sample Construction, and Data #### A. Empirical Design We estimate country random effects logit regression models. The dependent variable is equal to one if there are large-scale layoffs, management turnover, or major asset sales. The independent variables are investor protection, labor laws, financial leverage, and ownership concentration. Control variables are firm size and the previous year's operating performance. We include leverage because Ofek (1993) and Kang and Shivdasani (1997) find that leverage increases investors' ability to force large-scale layoffs and management turnover. Ownership concentration is included because it helps shareholders internalize the benefits oftaking action. We expect ownership concentration to be positively related to value-enhancing restructuring actions. We also account for the interactions between leverage and investor protection, and leverage and labor laws. The disciplining role of leverage should depend on the legal protection of creditors and shareholders because strong creditor rights make the threat of bankruptcy more credible, while strong shareholder rights make it more likely for firms to take advantage of the threat of bankruptcy. Thus, we expect the leverage effect to be stronger as investor protection increases. Leverage also has a role in strengthening shareholders bargaining position vis- $\grave{\cdot}\grave{\mathbf{a}}$ -vis labor. Bronars and Deere (1991) show that financial leverage reduces the power of labor unions because the increased threat of bankruptcy due to leverage makes it easier to extract concessions from unions. Thus, we hypothesize that the ability of union laws to deter layoffs and asset sales becomes weaker with higher financial leverage. Labor laws consist of two components: union laws and employee contract laws. They have a correlation coefficient of0.3264. Correlations among investor protection, the interaction terms, and the labor variables are all high. In order to properly identify the coefficients on the labor variables, regressions are estimated separately for each. For all specifications we perform the Breusch and Pagan (1980) test. The test statistics suggest the presence of unobserved country-level heterogeneity. Thus, when regressions contain country-level explanatory variables, we use country random effects; otherwise, we use country fixed effects. We also use year fixed effects to control for possible macroeconomic factors (e.g., financial crises and recessions) and industry fixed effects at the two-digit SIC level to control for industry-wide factors affecting restructuring decisions.9 Following Norton, Wang, and Ai (2004), we correct the coefficients on the interaction terms for the nonlinearity of the logit specification. #### B. Sample Construction The primary source of our firm-level data is Worldscope. We identify 25,698 industrial companies with sufficient data to conduct our tests from 41 countries over the period 1993 to 2004.10 From these firms we look for initially healthy firms that suffered a sharp drop in operating performance, measured by EBITDA/TA, where EBITDA is earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization, and TA is total assets. Table I contains the descriptions of all variables used in the paper. We use an accounting-based measure of operating performance instead of a stock price-based measure, because stock markets are forward looking and market values reflect the likelihood to undertake restructuring measures. For example, a more shareholder-friendly company may experience a smaller drop in valuation for the same decline in operating performance because of higher anticipation of value-enhancing restructuring. For layoffs and asset sales, our definition of poorly performing firms follows Kang and Shivdasani (1997). We require that the company initially have a positive, above-industry median EBITDA/TA in the base year and experience a drop of more than $50\%$ in EBITDA in the following year. This selection procedure yields 8,493 companies (10,904 firm-years). To identify poorly performing top management, we use a different criterion based on a relative performance measure. Consider the airline industry, which suffered a big drop in EBITDA after 9/11. When all airlines suffer losses, the performance of an airline's CEO should be judged relative to that of her rivals, not by an absolute measure. Thus, we follow Denis and Kruse (2ooo) and classify top management as underperforming if a company's EBITDA/TA is initially above the industry median and falls to the bottom quartile of its industry in the following year.11 This yields 6,988 firms (7,358 firm-years) with underperforming management. As a robustness check, we repeat the analyses using a sample based on the absolute measure of a $50\%$ drop in EBITDA for management turnover. The conclusions do not change.
